question: B 06 (b)
sols_html:
First pick any two linearly independent vectors lying in P (meaning the heads and tails of the vectors can be drawn in the plane P). A convenient choice will be two sides of the triangle T: (1, 1, 5) - (0, 1, 2) = (1, 0, 3) and (-1, 2, 2) - (0, 1, 2) = (-1, 1, 0).

A normal vector to the plane is given by the cross product of these two vectors (which is calculated in part (a) already):

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{N} = (1,0,3) \times (-1,1,0) = (-3,-3,1)\end{aligned}\]

The above vector gives the normal direction.

statement_html:
Consider the triangle T in three dimensions with vertices (0, 1, 2), (1, 1, 5) and (-1, 2, 2).

Consider also the plane P that contains T.

What is the normal (perpendicular) direction to P?
